chapter.title: The Flows tab
chapter.para: In this tab, the user can manage the Flows of the current Line. Note the similarity with the Projects and Lines tab.

tip.para: Instead of the buttons in toolbar, try using the context menu. To do so, right-click on a Flow that has been created. Notice that many features can be accessed through this method. For certain cases this is an easier and simpler choice.

section.title: Creating Flows
section.para: To create a Flow, follow the steps:

step.para: In the tab Projects and Lines, check that some Line is selected.

Go to Flows tab, then left-click on
.
A dialog box, named Flow "New Flow" Properties, will appear. Fill in the four standard fields: Title, Description (an one-line sentence), Author and an e-mail address. Click on OK when ready.

section.para: After a Flow has been created, it will be visible on the left side of the main window when the Flows tab is selected. The Details box, found on the right side of the main window, shows information about the selected Flow. The list of menus will appear automatically in a pop-up, and the user can assembling the flow (see ).

tip.para: The user can alter the position of the Flow in the list by dragging the Flow with the mouse to the desired position.
Observe that the information bar just below the menu Actions shows the parents Line and Project of the selected Flow.

section.title: Assembling the Flow
section.para: In GêBR, a Flow is a sequence of operations defined by the user. These operations, also called Flow's programsProgram, are organized into the following categories according to their purpose:

listitem.para: Gain, NMO, Stack and Standard Processes

section.para: After the Flow has been created and a pop-up appear with several menus, the user can assemble the Flow:

step.para: Choose one of them and include it in the Flow with a double-click.
If the user needs a specific order to the selected programs of the flow, just need drag and drop the desired programs.
The program inserted come enabled if it doesn't have required parameters.
To better configuration of the programs or if the program have required parameters, the user can edit their parameters (see how in )
To change status of a program, the user has to right-click over it and select the Enable, if program is disabled, or select Disable, if program is enabled (for more information, see )

tip.para:
If the user wants to change all programs, or a few, to the configured state simultaneously, he or she can select them by using
Ctrl Click . Then right-click on one of the selected programs, choose the option Configured from the menu that appeared. All the programs that were selected will be altered to the state
.

important.para:
To run a Flow all the programs listed in the Flow Sequence box must be Configured (
). Otherwise the Flow will not be executed as expected.

The state of a Flow, or a set of Flows, can be changed by using the hotkey Spacebar, which alters the state of the selected programs in the order Disabled and Enabled. The meaning of these states will be further described later on.

section.para:
The Flow is ready to be executed. Click on
to do it.

After the Flow has been, it will be visible on the left side of the main window when the Flows tab is selected. The Details box, found on the right side of the main window, shows information about the selected Flow .

tip.para: There is no limit on the number of Flows that can be created inside a Line.
The user can alter the position of the Flow in the list by dragging the Flow with the mouse to the desired position.
The information bar just bellow the menu Actions shows the complete Flow tree of the selected Flow.

section.title: Editing program's parameters
section.para: Program's parameters compose a set of initial configurations defined by the user.
To edit program's parameters the user must follow the steps below:

step.para:
Select the program from the Flow sequence box and click on
on the toolbar, or just double-click on the program. The Parameter box will appear on right side of window.
Edit the program's parameters. Notice that each program's parameter vary greatly both in size and type.

tip.para: The user can click on the Help button (bottom right corner of the dialog box) to view the program's documentation. This will be certainly useful when the user is editing the programs parameters.
The user can click on the Reset button when want the program to return to its default configurations.

step.para: All changes are saved automatically, and to close the parameter box, the user just need change selection on left side.

section.title: Changing a program's state
section.para:
The user can alternate between these states by using two methods: right-clicking on the program and then select the desired state from the context menu or using the shortcut
Spacebar to change the state(s) of the selected programs.

tip.para:
The user can select several programs whose state is desired to change by holding
Ctrl Click or
Shift Click .
Changing a program state does not alter its parameter configuration. The user can safely alternate between states.

important.para:
Disabled programs (
) will be ignored when the Flow runs. This way, the user can enable and disable parts of the Flow.

section.title: Editing the Flow's input and output files
section.para: To associate an input, output and error file to a Flow, the user must follow this steps:

mediaobject.caption: Select the Flow Editor Tab. In the Flow sequence box the user can edit the input, output and log files for this Flow sequence.

step.para: Select a Flow, in the Flows tab.
Below of the selected flow, the programs and entries with input, output and log files will be shown. The user can edit files paths by double clicking on them.

section.para: If the user wants to use the folders associated to the Line, can either choose like above or the user can use the feature of autocomplete of the important folders of this Line. (For more information, see ).

mediaobject.caption: Autocomplete feature in the Input file of a Flow.

section.para:
When the user chooses a path for the Flow's input/output, their file paths will appear in entries, indicated by the icons
and
, below and above the Flow's programs (if there are any).

note.para: If the user wishes to remove a set from the list, select them by pressing right-click and then click on Exclude.

section.title: Copying, pasting and deleting Flows and Programs
section.para: The clipboard provides the popular set of tools known as copy and paste. In GêBR, a Flow (or set of Flows) can be copied to the clipboard and paste back to the same Line or to other Lines. In the same manner, a program (or set of programs) can be copied to the clipboard too, and can be paste to the same Flow or to other Flows.

To copy Flows or programs to the clipboard, first select them with the mouse, and then use the button
or press the usual shortcut
Ctrl C . After copying the user can paste it by clicking on the button
or by simply using the shortcut
Ctrl V .

To delete a Flow (or set of Flows) and a Program (or set a Programs), select them then click on
.

tip.para:
The user can handle several Flows at once by holding
Ctrl Left-click or
Shift Left-click .

caution.para: GêBR does not ask for confirmation before deleting programs from a Flow.

section.title: Editing Flow's properties
section.para:
To edit Flow's properties the user must first select the Flow, then click on
.
In the Flows properties dialog box the user can edit the fields Title, Description, Author and Email.

section.title: Taking a snapshot of a flow
section.para: There are situations when working with GêBR it will be useful to use an existing flow as a basis to create new flows. For example, to experiment with flows that are only slightly different from one another, however without having to discard or modify the original flow.

A way to do this is to copy and paste the flow (see the section . Another way is to take a snapshot of the original flow, then edit it to the heart desire, and when the user wishes return the flow to its original state.

A very useful tool in GêBR is the snapshot. Through a snapshot, GêBR stores the settings of your flow so the user can come back to it later. All snapshots of the flow are presented in the flows tab. To take a snapshot of a flow:

step.para: Select the flow and left-click on More button on Toolbar.

Then click on
Take a Snapshot.
It's really necessary to write a description of the snapshot in the dialog box Save the snapshot description, to identify this saved state later on.
Left-click on OK to save your snapshot

note.para: Useful keybinds are available here: Ctrl+S takes a snapshot of the selected flow.
There is no limit on the number of snapshots for each flow.

section.para: To see the saved snapshots, just left-click on

If a snapshot of a flow was taken and for some reason undesired modifications were made to it, is possible to revert to the desired snapshot through double-click on the snapshot that is desired to revert. Whenever a snapshot is reverted, the dialog Backup Current State will appear.
Dialog of Backup Current State
Dialog of Backup Current State.
Clicking on Take a snapshot and proceed the dialog Save the snapshot description will appear, where is possible save this new snapshot. Clicking on Proceed discarding changes, GêBR will simply revert to the chosen snapshot without saving the current state.

tip.para: If the current state was previously saved, GêBR recommends that the user click on Proceed discarding changes, in the dialog box Backup Current State, as to avoid a bloated snapshot view.

caution.para: GêBR continuously saves the list of Flow states. Even if the computer was turned off, this list will be recovered when GêBR is opened again. However, if the flow was deleted all the saved states will immediately disappear forever.

section.para: Through a right-click over the target snapshot, the user has the option to execute, delete or revert it. The right-click over the current stage (Now) allows the user to Run the current flow or to take a snapshot thereof.

In this view, also is possible use multiple selection just click over several snapshots and the actions are disposable through the right-click over a snapshot. After to choose several snapshots and the action, this action will be applied in all selected snapshots.

To deselect a snapshot is as easy as select one, the user just need to click over the undesired snapshot. Also is possible deselect all the selected snapshots by clicking on the white area in this view.

Below is an example of the snapshot use:
Example of Snapshot use
Example of Snapshot use.

A user that uses different versions of the same flow may also be benefited by the use of snapshots. An option would be to save many different flows, one for each version, which drawback is the pollution of the flows tab. Another option, using the feature above, is taking a snapshot of each version of the flow. For instance, in the figure, the user would be storing two versions derived from 'B'.
The graph indicates from which version each snapshot was derived from. For instance, in the graph of the figure, is possible to see that the snapshot 'B' was based on the snapshot 'A'.

note.para: GêBR deals with the idea of origin of the snapshot. In the graph of the figure, 'B1' and 'B2' come from 'B' which, by its turn, comes from 'A'. If the user deletes 'B', GêBR will consider 'B1'and 'B2' as originated from 'A'.

section.title: Importing/Exporting a Flow
section.para: Although GêBR maintains all the data, the user still might wish to copy the Flows to file to be able to share them, for instance.
In the window Save Flow, navigate to a desired directory and type a name for the file (GêBR will automatically determine the extension flw). To do so:

step.para: In case of Import, the user must first select a Flow (or see , if one does not exist).

Select the tab Flows and left-click on
to import or on
to export.
Navigate through the files and select the Flow that is desired to be imported/export.

section.para: In case of Import, the imported Flow will be listed along with any other Flows of the selected Line. Otherwise, in case of Export, the file containing the exported Flow will be created.

section.title: Executing a flow
section.para: More than one flow can be selected, and then execute them all. To make a multiple selection, click over the flows, while Ctrl is pressed or use the arrow keys while Shift is pressed.

section.title: Run
section.para:
By clicking on
, the job will be triggered with the following settings:
In case of multiple flows, the default is executing one after another.
The flow (or flows) selected is (are) going to be executed immediately.
If the flow is parallelizable, the job will be dispatched on all group's nodes. If not parallelizable, it's necessary to choose the best node.
Parallelizable flows are going to be splitted by nominal capacity (total number of cores). If not parallelizable, the flow will not be splitted. (For more information, see ).
The flow execution is going to compete for resources with other processes. (For more information, see ).
It is a fast way to execute, skipping the configurations of the Run and Setup.

note.para: Some execution configuration (like group's nodes, number of tasks splitted and priority) can be saved using Setup and Run. That configuration is going to be a new default for basic Run. (For more information, see )
Useful keybinds are available here: Ctrl+R runs the selected Flows one after another; Ctrl+Shift+R runs the selected Flows parallely (keybind activated just if multiple Flows are selected).

section.title: Run and Setup
section.para: Many execution details can be set before triggering a Job. After setting, click on Run to execute the job.

By clicking over
, it can be set:
How jobs are going to be executed. This option just appear if multiple jobs are selected for running (multiple execution).
One after another: Flows can be executed one after another, in the order they are on the Flows list. Each flow awaits for the end of the previous job to be executed.
Simultaneously: Flows are executed parallely, all of them at the same time. It is just possible if there is no dependency between Flows.
Whether jobs must wait for some task or not. Jobs can be triggered after the ending of another task or immediately by clicking the execution button.
Where jobs must be dispatched. Nodes or set of nodes can be choosen to process the Jobs. A special option is the Choose automatically. It allows the Maestro to search for the least overloaded nodes or set of nodes. If the use changes this parameter, GêBR shows the number of cores of the choosen group.
The number of tasks settled to split the jobs. This parameter is valid only when there is a parallelizable job among the selected jobs. The nominal capacity is given by the number of cores, according to the choice of the group's nodes. For non-parallelizable jobs, this parameter is automatically set to 1. For more information, consult .
How a job must compete with other processes on the system. In overloaded nodes, this option can make all the difference because jobs will have less priority than other processes running on the system. For more information, consult .

note.para: Itens 3, 4 and 5 can be saved for future executions by checking Save Preferences.

section.title: Executing a Flow multiple times
section.para: The program LoopLoop (from the category Loops) has a totally different usage compared to the remaining programs from GêBR. The user is going to see some of these differences.

When the user adds the program Loop, it always appears on the top of the Flow. That happens to indicate that the Flow is going to be executed more than once, according to the parameters set for the program. (see for further details).

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of program Loop, added to a Flow and properly configured.

section.para: After the Loop is added, the user has access to a new variable, the iter (see ). The value of this special variable is modified on each iteration (increasing or decrementing), according to the parameters set.

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of the edition from parameters of Loop program, with a simple example of parameters setting.

section.title: Editing comments
section.para: This button appears in the Projects and Lines tab and in Flows tab. This button allows the user to add commentsReportof a Flow about the selected Line or Flow. See .

section.title: View Report
section.para: This button appears in the Projects and Lines tab and in Flows tab. This button allows the user to View the Report about the Line or Flow in use. The difference is that the Line's Report can include the Flow's Report. All other functions are described in .
